title: Attractive Valuation Post-Correction
text: In the aftermath of a major correction in the major indexes, tech stocks have been rattled by negative sentiment. A lacklustre quarter for Apple further subjected it to the wrath of a major selloff. As the dust begins to settle, I see a very good opportunity to once again invest in Apple, which should rebound swiftly given its robust product line, innovation, and gradual shift in focus towards its services segment with higher retention rates and commendable gross margins.

comments.commentText: While the stock has gotten cheaper, still doubt its at its lowest point. I think there is still a lot more downside to be priced in, especially given that competitors are evidently taking away Apple's market share through undercutting and comparable, if not superior, products (in one way or another).
Agree with OP, and disagree with comment above.

title: The Struggle Against Generics
text: After an impressive 2018 performance, Pfizer once again faces its decades-old nemesis: generic drugs. With the imminent expiry of patents covering some of its most valuable drugs in its pipeline, it is unclear whether Pfizer has what it takes to ramp up innovation and preserve a competitive moat to enhance its revenue stream. For now, it is difficult to find any further upside from its current valuation.

comments.commentText: I think it'll take a while for Pfizer to enhance its pipelines with novel drugs. FWIW, they have ample cash to spend on drugs R&D and acquisitions. Still a 50/50 for me at this current price point.

title: AMD, the Dark Horse of 2019
text: With the rollout of highly competitive products at growing margins, AMD looks set to put up impressive quarterly earnings. Ramping up in areas of product innovation and cost efficiency, AMD's primary competitors and current market leaders Intel and Nvidia better be on their toes.

comments.commentText: Hmm.. they may be getting better alright, but their valuation has already surged way past industry multiples. I'd say enter with care, and if you're long-term invested, don't go all in yet.

title: Tesla's Valuation Bubble
text: Despite strong segment performance with impressive sales for the Model S, it is far from justifying the high PEG ratio premium currently priced in. Profitability remains as the primary issue of concern, with cash burn and leverage levels still at an alarming rate against the current volatility and perceived unstability of the macroeconomic backdrop.

comments.commentText: Put very nicely. If anything, Tesla's current market cap can only be rationalized by a cult-like following and an over-optimistic market sentiment. Any signs of a pull-back in valuation will likely trigger a significant sell-off.

Put very nicely. If anything, Tesla's current market cap can only be rationalized by a cult-like following and an over-optimistic market sentiment. Any signs of a pull-back in valuation will likely trigger a significant sell-off.

Hard to say with these sort of cash-burn, high-growth potential companies. While technically there hasn't been any surplus returns (to retail investors), to say this stock is overvalued based on balance sheet fundamentals alone may not accurately reflect how the market fairly prices Tesla.
